web_search.ai_response:
I will run a targeted web search to collect authoritative information about the NEURON simulation environment (its purpose, features, licensing, and where to find documentation and downloads). I'll prioritize official sources (NEURON website, documentation, tutorials) and major repositories or academic descriptions.## Plan / next step
I searched authoritative sites (NEURON official site, ReadTheDocs, tutorials) to collect current, citable information about the NEURON simulator. With these results, I will summarize NEURON’s purpose, core features, installation pointers, documentation/tutorial resources, and provide direct links so you can dive deeper.

## Overview — what NEURON is
- **NEURON** — a simulation environment for modeling neurons and networks of neurons with anatomically and biophysically detailed models. It is widely used in research and teaching for compartmental modeling, ion channel dynamics, synapses, reaction–diffusion (RxD), network simulations, and coupling to optimized backends (CoreNEURON).

## Key features (from the official docs)
- Multi-compartment neuron modeling with arbitrary morphologies and membrane mechanisms.
- Programming interfaces: **Python**, **HOC**, and a graphical interface.
- Support for custom membrane mechanisms via MOD files and NMODL (and guidance for adapting MOD files for newer NEURON versions).
- Reaction–diffusion (RxD) modeling for intracellular and extracellular chemical dynamics.
- Tools for visualization, parameter exploration, and optimization (e.g., Multiple Run Fitter).
- Integration with CoreNEURON for HPC/GPU-accelerated simulations and compatibility notes included in docs.
- Extensive examples, tutorials, and community forum for support.

## Installation pointers (official guidance)
- Recommended install via pip for most platforms:
  - pip3 install neuron
- Platform-specific installers and instructions are available:
  - Windows: downloadable installer (also WSL recommended option)
  - macOS / Linux: pip or platform packages; source build instructions if needed
- NEURON is available on cloud platforms (e.g., Google Colab) and on platforms such as The Neuroscience Gateway and EBRAINS.
- For MOD/NMODL compatibility with NEURON >= 9.0 there are specific migration notes in the docs.

## Documentation & learning resources (important links)
- NEURON official site (community, installers, forum, news, tutorials):  
  [NEURON | empirically-based simulations of neurons and networks](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/)
- Main documentation site / user guide:  
  [The NEURON Simulator — NEURON documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/)
  - Contains installation instructions, user guides, NEURON Python docs, CoreNEURON docs, training videos, and examples.
- Tutorials and guides on NEURON site:  
  [Guides and tutorials - NEURON](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/neuron/docs)
- Classic programming tutorial (introductory step‑by‑step):  
  [NEURON Programming Tutorial #1](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/static/docs/tutorial/prog1b.html)
- External tutorial mirror / classic resource (MIT-hosted tutorial):  
  [NEURON Tutorial - MIT](http://web.mit.edu/neuron_v7.4/nrntuthtml/index.html)

## Community & model repositories
- NEURON Forum (installation help, examples, community Q&A) — linked from the NEURON site and docs.
- ModelDB (collection of published NEURON models) — accessible via links on the NEURON site & docs.

## Quick recommendations for getting started
- If you want a quick start with Python notebooks: install with pip (pip3 install neuron) and run the example “Ball and stick” tutorials on the ReadTheDocs site.  
- If you plan to use or adapt legacy MOD files, consult the NEURON docs section about adapting MOD/NMODL for NEURON >= 9.0 before running nrnivmodl.
- Use the NEURON forum for concrete installation or model-building questions — it’s actively used by the community.

## Sources / where this came from
- NEURON official site: [NEURON | empirically-based simulations of neurons and networks](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/)  
- NEURON documentation on ReadTheDocs: [The NEURON Simulator — NEURON documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/)  
- NEURON docs (guides & tutorials): [Guides and tutorials - NEURON](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/neuron/docs)  
- NEURON Programming Tutorial #1: [NEURON Programming Tutorial #1](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/static/docs/tutorial/prog1b.html)  
- MIT-hosted NEURON tutorial: [NEURON Tutorial - MIT](http://web.mit.edu/neuron_v7.4/nrntuthtml/index.html)

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
    if total_items is not None and len(all_morphs) >= total_items:
        break

    page += 1

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(all_morphs)}\")
```

Notes:
- The entitysdk has multiple helpers; if it exposes a `.all()` or `.iterate()` convenience that automatically pages, prefer that. Example from docs: `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()`.
- Always check the client response structure for fields like `items`, `total_items`, `limit`, `offset`, or built-in iterators.

---

## 3) Using the entitysdk convenience method shown in examples (single call)

The entitysdk examples show a convenient pattern using search_entity(...).all() to fetch results. If the SDK supports retrieving all with `.all()`, use that:

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# If the client supports .all() to fetch everything (with internal paging)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

print(f\Total morphologies returned: {len(morphs)}\")
for m in morphs[:10]:  # show first 10
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 4) Filtering examples (by mtype or species)

You can pass query filters to narrow results (examples from docs):

- Find morphologies for a specific MType label:

```python
morphs_sr_pc = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\mtype__pref_label\": \SR_PC\"}
).all()
```

- Limit by species (scientific name):

```python
morphs_mouse = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\subject__species__name\": \Mus musculus\"}
).all()
```

---

## Important Platform / EntityCore rules (summary)

- When calling GET ALL endpoints, mention and check `total_items`. Ask before using extra pages if you need to avoid large downloads.
- The EntityCore examples show `client.search_entity(...).all()` as a convenient approach; it may already page for you.
- The SDK examples in the repo demonstrate additional workflows: uploading assets, registering morphologies, adding MType classifications \u2014 see the entitysdk examples for full patterns.

---

If you\u2019d like:
- I can produce a ready-to-run script tailored to your auth method (API key / OAuth) \u2014 tell me which auth you use.
- Or I can show an example using explicit entitycore API parameters (page, page_size) adapted to the exact client methods you have \u2014 tell me which entitysdk version or client functions you see.

Below are concise, copy-paste-ready examples and notes based on the official entitysdk documentation. These snippets assume you already have an authenticated `client` object (the examples in the docs use a pre-configured `client` variable).

### Quick explanation of the approach
Use the `client.search_entity` helper with `entity_type=models.CellMorphology` and optional query / pagination parameters. Results are returned as an iterator you can iterate over or convert to a list.

---

### 1) Retrieve a limited number (e.g., 10) of cell morphologies
```python
from entitysdk import models

# Retrieve up to 10 CellMorphology entities
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=models.CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(\Retrieved:", len(morphs))
for m in morphs:
    print(f\ID: {m.id}  Name: {m.name}")
```

---

### 2) Search by name (case-insensitive, SQL ILIKE pattern)
```python
from entitysdk import models

# Case-insensitive name search; supports wildcard patterns like '%my-morph%'
hits = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=models.CellMorphology,
    query={
ame__ilike": \my-morph"},   # adjust pattern as needed
    query_extra={\page": 1, \page_size": 2},  # optional pagination controls
    limit=None   # use None to allow retrieving more (see notes below)
).all()

print(\Number of results:", len(hits))
```

---

### 3) Filter by mtype preferred label (example: 'SR_PC' or 'L5_TPC:A')
```python
from entitysdk import models

morphs = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=models.CellMorphology,
    query={\mtype__pref_label": \SR_PC"},
    limit=50
).all()

for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name, m.mtype)
```

---

### 4) Iterate results without collecting into memory
If you expect many results and want to stream them instead of loading all at once:
```python
from entitysdk import models

iterator = client.search_entity(entity_type=models.CellMorphology, limit=None)

for m in iterator:
    # process each morphology one at a time
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## Practical notes and tips
- **Limit vs. pagination**: Setting `limit=None` lets the iterator fetch as many results as the API will provide; you can also use `page`/`page_size` in the `query` (or `query_extra`) for manual pagination.
- **Common filter keys** (from docs): `name__ilike`, `mtype__pref_label`, `subject__species__name`, and many other entity fields — pass them in the `query` dictionary.
- **Fields returned**: Each returned `CellMorphology` object includes `.id`, `.name`, `.description`, `.mtype`, measurement metadata, and other attributes documented in the entitysdk models.
- **Memory**: Use the iterator approach for large result sets to avoid storing everything in memory.

---

If you want, I can:
- Show an example that restricts morphologies to a specific brain region (need the brain region ID), or
- Provide a complete example including client creation/authentication steps (tell me how you authenticate or which auth method you use).

## Simulation Costs

Simulation costs depend on your plan (Free or Pro) and the type of simulation you're running.

### Simulation Costs by Plan

| Simulation Type | Free Plan | Pro Plan |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|
| **E-model** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Ion channel** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Single cell** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Synaptome** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Small microcircuit** (≤10 neurons) | 10 credits/simulation | 5 credits/simulation |
| **Microcircuit** (>10 neurons) | 0.05 credits/neuron/second of biological time | 0.025 credits/neuron/second of biological time |

### Credits Included

- **Free Plan:** 100 free initial credits (expire in 1 year)
- **Pro Plan Monthly:** 50 free credits/month (CHF 25/month)
- **Pro Plan Yearly:** 650 free credits/year (CHF 275/year)

### Cost Savings with Pro

The Pro plan offers approximately **50% cost reduction** on all simulation types:
- Basic simulations: 0.5 vs 1 credit
- Small microcircuits: 5 vs 10 credits
- Large microcircuits: Half the per-neuron cost

### Example Calculations

- **10 single cell simulations on Free:** 10 credits
- **10 single cell simulations on Pro:** 5 credits
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Free:** 5 credits (100 × 0.05)
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Pro:** 2.5 credits (100 × 0.025)

Source: OBI pricing plans (Sanity planV2).

platform_viewing.user: what is this ? what am i looking at
platform_viewing.expected_output:
Summary — what you're looking at
You are viewing a list or collection of cell morphologies filtered to a specific brain region. The platform context shows:

Observed entity type: cell-morphology
Within brain region ID: 2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd
Within brain region annotation value: 477
This means the page is showing neuronal morphological reconstructions (digital neuron shapes — soma, dendrites, axon, measurements and metadata) that are associated with the brain region whose internal ID is 2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd (annotation value 477).

What a "cell morphology" entry typically contains
Each cell morphology record on this page usually includes:

ID and Name of the morphology entry
Species / subject information (e.g., Mus musculus)
Brain region (the region the neuron was recorded/reconstructed from)
M-type(s) or morphological classification
Quantitative measurements (e.g., dendritic length, soma size) and associated units/statistics
A short description and provenance (contributor, publication)
Downloadable assets (morphology files) and viewable visualizations
Why the brain region ID matters
The platform uses atlas-driven searches. The page is constrained to show only morphologies that live within (or were assigned to) the brain region represented by the UUID 2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd. The numeric annotation value shown (477) is the atlas annotation corresponding to that region.

Next steps I can take for you
Resolve the brain region UUID to its human-readable name and show the first page of matching cell-morphology entries (includes count, and a list of items with key metadata).
Show details for a specific morphology if you click/select one (or tell me which ID/name you want).
Download a morphology asset or list available assets for an entry.
Tell me which of these you want me to do and I’ll proceed. (I can automatically resolve the region name and fetch the first page of morphologies unless you prefer something else.)
platform_viewing.ai_response:
You're looking at a data-browse view from the Open Brain Platform, focused on a mouse brain region. Here’s how to interpret the context you provided and what you’re likely seeing:

## What you’re viewing
- **Brain Region**: The data is scoped to a specific brain region, identified by a UUID (e.g., br_id 2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd). This is the parent region in which other entities are studied.
- **Observed Entity Type**: **cell-morphology** — you’re exploring neuronal morphology data (soma shape, dendritic/arborization patterns, axon projections) within that brain region.
- **Current Entity ID**: None, meaning you haven’t selected a specific morphology specimen yet.

software_docs_obione.user: Please show me a code example of how to create a single cell simulation using the obione package.
software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Notes, tips and placeholders
- **Replace** <MEMODEL-ID> with the actual MEModel UUID from EntityCore.
- You need a configured db_client variable (OBI-One examples use a DB client for GridScan generation) \u2014 ensure you have credentials and environment set up as per your installation.
- If you prefer to pick an MEModel interactively or via EntityCore queries, use the platform's EntityCore helpers to get MEModel IDs (examples in the repository show interactive selection).
- The examples above are adapted from the OBI-One example notebooks:
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_with_synapses_simulation.ipynb

If you want, I can:
- provide a minimal runnable script adjusted to your environment (if you give me the MEModel ID and where your db_client/config is stored),
- or show how to query EntityCore for available MEModels and pick one programmatically. Which would you like?
software_docs_obione.ai_response:
I will first locate the correct OBI package documentation for the obione library so I can base the example on the official API; next I'll fetch the latest docs for that library to produce a concise, correct code example.## Overview

Below is a concise, practical example showing how to create and run a single-cell (MEModel) simulation using the **obi-one** (obione) package. It follows the documented workflow: authenticate & initialize the client, build a simulation configuration (timestamps, stimulus, recordings, initialize), validate the config, and execute the simulation grid scan / run.

This example is a suggested starting configuration — replace placeholder IDs and parameters with your chosen MEModel ID and project settings.

---

### Example: Single-cell MEModel simulation with obi-one

```python
# Required imports (from documentation)
from entitysdk import Client
from obi_auth import get_token
from obi_notebook import get_projects, get_entities
import obi_one as obi

# 1) Authentication & client setup
# Obtain an auth token and project context (adjust environment/auth_mode as needed)
token = get_token(environment=\production", auth_mode=\daf")
project_context = get_projects.get_projects(token)

# Create the EntitySDK client bound to your project context
db_client = Client(environment=\production", project_context=project_context, token_manager=token)

# 2) Select MEModel to simulate
# Option A: specify a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = "<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< replace with your MEModel ID

if entity_ID != "<MEMODEL-ID>":
    memodel_ids = [entity_ID]
else:
    # Option B: interactively select from available MEModels for the project
    memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel", token, [],
                                           project_context=project_context,
                                           multi_select=False,
                                           default_scale=\small")

# 3) Build the MEModel simulation configuration
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Start with an empty MEModelSimulationScanConfig
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info: campaign name / description
info = obi.Info(campaign_name=\MEModel Single-Cell Simulation",
                campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current clamp")
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info")

# Regular timestamps (3 repetitions in example)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0,
                                           number_of_repetitions=3,
                                           interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name=\RegularTimestamps")

# Stimulus: somatic constant current clamp
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (adjust amplitude as needed)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput")

# Recordings: soma voltage and a time-windowed recording
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name=\VoltageRecording")

time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name=\TimeWindowVoltageRecording")

# Initialization: point the config at the chosen MEModel ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=memodel_ids[0]),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name=\initialize")

# 4) Validate the configuration (produces a validated config object)
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()

# 5) Generate a grid scan (if you want parameter sweeps) and execute
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(form=validated_sim_conf,
                                       coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX",
                                       output_root="./obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan")

# Optional: inspect multiple-value and coordinate parameters
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation of scan and run tasks via db client
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
obi.run_tasks_for_generated_scan(grid_scan, db_client=db_client)

# 6) Run simulation with a simulator backend (example: BlueCelluLab)
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

simulation_config_path = grid_scan.generated_config_path  # path produced by generation step
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulator= luecellulab",
    save_nwb=False
)
```

---

## Notes & next steps

- The example above follows the documented notebook examples from the obi-one repository; replace **<MEMODEL-ID>** with the MEModel you want to simulate or use the interactive selection.
- Adjust stimulus amplitude/duration, recording windows, and simulation duration to match your experimental aims.
- With this configuration validated and run, the next step will be checking produced outputs (logs, result directories, NWB files if saved) and inspecting recorded soma voltages to analyze the cell's response. If you want, I can show how to parse NWB output or how to convert this to a single-run (no grid scan) minimal script.
